001package squidpony.squidmath;
002
003import squidpony.ArrayTools;
004
005import java.io.Serializable;
006import java.util.*;
007
008import static squidpony.squidmath.NumberTools.intBitsToFloat;
009
010/**
011 * A wrapper class for working with random number generators in a more friendly way.
012 * Implements {@link IRNG}, which covers most of the API surface, but RNG implements
013 * a decent amount of additional methods. You should consider if your code needs
014 * these additional methods, and if not you should use IRNG as the type for when you
015 * need some random number generator.
016 * <p>
017 * Includes methods for getting values between two numbers and for getting
018 * random elements from a collection or array. There are methods to shuffle
019 * a collection and to get a random ordering that can be applied as one shuffle
020 * across multiple collections, such as via {@link OrderedMap#reorder(int...)},
021 * {@link ArrayTools#reorder(ArrayList, int...)}, and so on. You can construct
022 * an RNG with all sorts of RandomnessSource implementations, and choosing them
023 * is usually not a big concern because the default works very well. If you target
024 * GWT, then it is suggested that you use {@link GWTRNG} instead of RNG; both
025 * implement {@link IRNG}, which is enough for most usage across SquidLib, but
026 * GWTRNG is optimized heavily for better performance on GWT, even returning long
027 * values faster than implementations that natively do their math on longs. It has
028 * worse performance on 64-bit PCs and mobile devices, but should also have better
029 * performance on 32-bit PCs and mobile devices.
030 * <br>
031 * But if you do want advice on what RandomnessSource to use... {@link DiverRNG}
032 * is the default, and is the fastest generator that passes most tests and can
033 * produce all 64-bit values, and though relative to many of the others it has a
034 * significantly shorter period (the amount of random numbers it will go through
035 * before repeating the sequence), this almost never matters in games, and is
036 * primarily relevant for massively-parallel scientific programs. DiverRNG has a
037 * period of {@code pow(2, 64)} as opposed to {@link XoRoRNG}'s
038 * {@code pow(2, 128) - 1}, or {@link LongPeriodRNG}'s {@code pow(2, 1024) - 1}.
039 * {@link LightRNG} is a solid choice and a former default RandomnessSource;
040 * additional features of LightRNG are exposed in {@link MoonwalkRNG} and using
041 * MoonwalkRNG is recommended if you need unusual features like skipping backwards
042 * in a random number sequence, taking a result of a nextLong() call and reversing
043 * it to get the state that produced it, or calculating the distance in number of
044 * nextLong() calls between two results of nextLong() calls. LightRNG is a
045 * StatefulRandomness, which lets it be used in {@link StatefulRNG}, and so is
046 * DiverRNG, but LightRNG is also a {@link SkippingRandomness}, which means you can
047 * leap forward or backwards in its sequence very efficiently (DiverRNG is not a
048 * SkippingRandomness). {@link ThrustAltRNG} provides similar qualities to LightRNG,
049 * and is one of the fastest generators here, but can't produce all possible 64-bit
050 * values (possibly some 32-bit values as well); it was the default at one point so
051 * you may want to keep compatibility with some versions by specifying ThrustAltRNG.
052 * The defaults have changed in the past as issues are found in various generators;
053 * LightRNG has high quality all-around but is slower than the other defaults,
054 * ThrustAltRNG can't produce all results, LinnormRNG passed tests in an earlier
055 * version of the PractRand test suite but now fails in the current version, and now
056 * the default is DiverRNG, which shares the known issue of LightRNG and LinnormRNG
057 * that it can't produce the same result twice from {@link #nextLong()} until the
058 * generator exhausts its period and repeats its output from the beginning.
059 * For most cases, you should decide between DiverRNG, ThrustAltRNG, LightRNG,
060 * LongPeriodRNG, MiniMover64RNG, and XoshiroStarPhi32RNG based on your priorities.
061 * Some tasks are better solved by using a different class, usually {@link GWTRNG},
062 * which can always be serialized on GWT to save its state easily and is usually the
063 * fastest substitute for RNG on that platform. DiverRNG is the best if you want high
064 * speed, very good quality of randomness, and expect to generate a reasonable quantity
065 * of numbers for a game (less than 18446744073709551616 numbers) without any single
066 * results being impossible. LightRNG is the second-best at the above criteria, but is
067 * the best option if you need an RNG that can skip backwards or jump forwards without
068 * incurring speed penalties. LongPeriodRNG is best if you for some reason need a massive
069 * amount of random numbers (as in, ten quintillion would be far too little) or want to
070 * split up such a large generator into unrelated subsequences. XoshiroStarPhi32RNG is
071 * best if GWT is a possible target but you either need to generate more than
072 * 18446744073709551616 numbers (but less than 340282366920938463463374607431768211455
073 * numbers) or you need to ensure that each 128-bit chunk of output is unique; if GWT is
074 * a target but those specific needs don't matter, use GWTRNG. ThrustAltRNG and
075 * MiniMover64RNG are both faster than DiverRNG usually (MiniMover64RNG is the fastest),
076 * but because they are unable to generate some outputs, that may make them a poor choice
077 * for some usage (ThrustAltRNG also has some bias toward specific numbers and produces
078 * them more frequently, but not frequently enough to make it fail statistical tests, and
079 * ThrustAltRNG can skip around in its output sequence like LightRNG).
080 * <br>
081 * There are many more RandomnessSource implementations! You might want significantly less
082 * predictable random results, which  {@link IsaacRNG} can provide, along with a
083 * large period. The quality of {@link PermutedRNG} is also good, usually, and it
084 * has a sound basis in PCG-Random, an involved library with many variants on its
085 * RNGs.
086 * <br>
087 * There may be reasons why you would want a random number generator that uses 32-bit
088 * math instead of the more common 64-bit math, but using a 32-bit int on desktop and
089 * Android won't act the same as that same 32-bit int on GWT. Since GWT is stuck with
090 * JavaScript's implementation of ints with doubles, overflow (which is needed for an
091 * RNG) doesn't work with ints as expected, but does with GWT's implementation of longs.
092 * If targeting GWT, you should probably consider {@link GWTRNG} or {@link SilkRNG},
093 * which would be used in place of this class and have a similar API. You can instead
094 * choose a RandomnessSource that is efficient on GWT; {@link Lathe32RNG} is
095 * significantly faster at producing int values on GWT than any long-based generator,
096 * and will produce the same results on GWT as on desktop or Android (not all 32-bit
097 * generators do this). {@link Starfish32RNG} goes one step further than Lathe32RNG at
098 * an even distribution, and has better quality, but is slightly slower; it is also used
099 * internally by GWTRNG. While Lathe32RNG can produce all ints over the course of its
100 * period, it will produce some pairs of ints, or longs, more often than others and will
101 * never produce some longs. Starfish32RNG will produce all longs but one.
102 * {@link Oriole32RNG} and {@link XoshiroStarPhi32RNG} are also GWT-safe, but other
103 * generators that were thought to be GWT-friendly are not. {@link PintRNG} is a
104 * GWT-unsafe generators with other uses, but should not be used on GWT. All other
105 * RandomnessSources use longs, and so will be slower than the recommended Starfish32RNG
106 * or Lathe32RNG on GWT, but probably are much faster on 64-bit JREs.
107 * @author Eben Howard - http://squidpony.com - howard@squidpony.com
108 * @author Tommy Ettinger
109 * @author smelC
110 */
111public class RNG implements Serializable, IRNG {
112
113        protected RandomnessSource random;
114        protected Random ran = null;
115
116    private static final long serialVersionUID = 2352426757973945105L;
117
118
119    /**
120     * Default constructor; uses {@link DiverRNG}, which is of high quality, but low period (which rarely matters
121     * for games), and has excellent speed, tiny state size, and natively generates 64-bit numbers.
122     * <br>
123     * Previous versions of SquidLib used different implementations, including {@link LightRNG}, {@link ThrustAltRNG},
124     * {@link LinnormRNG}, and {@link MersenneTwister}. You can still use one of these by instantiating one of those
125     * classes and passing it to {@link #RNG(RandomnessSource)}, which may be the best way to ensure the same results
126     * across versions.
127     */
128    public RNG() {
129        this(new DiverRNG());
130    }
131
132    /**
133     * Default constructor; uses {@link DiverRNG}, which is of high quality, but low period (which rarely matters
134     * for games), and has excellent speed, tiny state size, and natively generates 64-bit numbers. The seed can be
135     * any long, including 0.
136     * @param seed any long
137     */
138    public RNG(long seed) {
139        this(new DiverRNG(seed));
140    }
141
142    /**
143     * String-seeded constructor; uses a platform-independent hash of the String (it does not use String.hashCode,
144     * instead using {@link CrossHash#hash64(CharSequence)}) as a seed for {@link DiverRNG}, which is of high quality,
145     * but low period (which rarely matters for games), and has excellent speed, tiny state size, and natively generates
146     * 64-bit numbers.
147     */
148    public RNG(CharSequence seedString) {
149        this(new DiverRNG(CrossHash.hash64(seedString)));
150    }
151
152    /**
153     * Uses the provided source of randomness for all calculations. This constructor should be used if an alternate
154     * RandomnessSource other than DiverRNG is desirable, such as to keep compatibility with earlier SquidLib
155     * versions that defaulted to MersenneTwister, LightRNG, ThrustAltRNG, or LinnormRNG.
156     * <br>
157     * If the parameter is null, this is equivalent to using {@link #RNG()} as the constructor.
158     * @param random the source of pseudo-randomness, such as a LightRNG or LongPeriodRNG object
159     */
160    public RNG(RandomnessSource random) {
161        this.random = (random == null) ? new DiverRNG() : random;
162    }
163
164    /**
165     * A subclass of java.util.Random that uses a RandomnessSource supplied by the user instead of the default.
166     *
167     * @author Tommy Ettinger
168     */
169    public static class CustomRandom extends Random {
170
171        private static final long serialVersionUID = 8211985716129281944L;
172        private final RandomnessSource randomnessSource;
173
174        /**
175         * Creates a new random number generator. This constructor uses
176         * a DiverRNG with a random seed.
177         */
178        public CustomRandom() {
179            randomnessSource = new DiverRNG();
180        }
181
182        /**
183         * Creates a new random number generator. This constructor uses
184         * the seed of the given RandomnessSource if it has been seeded.
185         *
186         * @param randomnessSource a way to get random bits, supplied by RNG
187         */
188        public CustomRandom(RandomnessSource randomnessSource) {
189            this.randomnessSource = randomnessSource;
190        }
191
192        /**
193         * Generates the next pseudorandom number. Subclasses should
194         * override this, as this is used by all other methods.
195         * <p>
196         * <p>The general contract of {@code next} is that it returns an
197         * {@code int} value and if the argument {@code bits} is between
198         * {@code 1} and {@code 32} (inclusive), then that many low-order
199         * bits of the returned value will be (approximately) independently
200         * chosen bit values, each of which is (approximately) equally
201         * likely to be {@code 0} or {@code 1}. The method {@code next} is
202         * implemented by class {@code Random} by atomically updating the seed to
203         * <pre>{@code (seed * 0x5DEECE66DL + 0xBL) & ((1L << 48) - 1)}</pre>
204         * and returning
205         * <pre>{@code (int)(seed >>> (48 - bits))}.</pre>
206         *
207         * This is a linear congruential pseudorandom number generator, as
208         * defined by D. H. Lehmer and described by Donald E. Knuth in
209         * <i>The Art of Computer Programming,</i> Volume 3:
210         * <i>Seminumerical Algorithms</i>, section 3.2.1.
211         *
212         * @param bits random bits
213         * @return the next pseudorandom value from this random number
214         * generator's sequence
215         * @since 1.1
216         */
217        @Override
218        protected int next(int bits) {
219            return randomnessSource.next(bits);
220        }
221
222        /**
223         * Returns the next pseudorandom, uniformly distributed {@code long}
224         * value from this random number generator's sequence. The general
225         * contract of {@code nextLong} is that one {@code long} value is
226         * pseudorandomly generated and returned.
227         *
228         * @return the next pseudorandom, uniformly distributed {@code long}
229         * value from this random number generator's sequence
230         */
231        @Override
232        public long nextLong() {
233            return randomnessSource.nextLong();
234        }
235    }
236
237    /**
238     * @return a Random instance that can be used for legacy compatibility
239     */
240    public Random asRandom() {
241        if (ran == null) {
242            ran = new CustomRandom(random);
243        }
244        return ran;
245    }
246
247    /**
248     * Returns a value from an even distribution from min (inclusive) to max
249     * (exclusive).
250     *
251     * @param min the minimum bound on the return value (inclusive)
252     * @param max the maximum bound on the return value (exclusive)
253     * @return the found value
254     */
255    @Override
256    public double between(double min, double max) {
257        return min + (max - min) * nextDouble();
258    }
259
260    /**
261     * Returns a value between min (inclusive) and max (exclusive).
262     * <br>
263     * The inclusive and exclusive behavior is to match the behavior of the similar
264     * method that deals with floating point values.
265     * <br>
266     * If {@code min} and {@code max} happen to be the same, {@code min} is returned
267     * (breaking the exclusive behavior, but it's convenient to do so).
268     *
269     * @param min the minimum bound on the return value (inclusive)
270     * @param max the maximum bound on the return value (exclusive)
271     * @return the found value
272     */
273    @Override
274    public int between(int min, int max) {
275        return nextInt(max - min) + min;
276    }
277
278    /**
279     * Returns a value between min (inclusive) and max (exclusive).
280     * <p>
281     * The inclusive and exclusive behavior is to match the behavior of the
282     * similar method that deals with floating point values.
283     *
284     * @param min the minimum bound on the return value (inclusive)
285     * @param max the maximum bound on the return value (exclusive)
286     * @return the found value
287     */
288    @Override
289    public long between(long min, long max) {
290        return nextLong(max - min) + min;
291    }
292
293    /**
294     * Returns the average of a number of randomly selected numbers from the
295     * provided range, with min being inclusive and max being exclusive. It will
296     * sample the number of times passed in as the third parameter.
297     * <p>
298     * The inclusive and exclusive behavior is to match the behavior of the
299     * similar method that deals with floating point values.
300     * <p>
301     * This can be used to weight RNG calls to the average between min and max.
302     *
303     * @param min     the minimum bound on the return value (inclusive)
304     * @param max     the maximum bound on the return value (exclusive)
305     * @param samples the number of samples to take
306     * @return the found value
307     */
308    public int betweenWeighted(int min, int max, int samples) {
309        int sum = 0;
310        for (int i = 0; i < samples; i++) {
311            sum += between(min, max);
312        }
313
314        return Math.round((float) sum / samples);
315    }
316
317    /**
318     * Returns a random element from the provided array and maintains object
319     * type.
320     *
321     * @param <T>   the type of the returned object
322     * @param array the array to get an element from
323     * @return the randomly selected element
324     */
325    @Override
326    public <T> T getRandomElement(T[] array) {
327        if (array.length < 1) {
328            return null;
329        }
330        return array[nextInt(array.length)];
331    }
332
333    /**
334     * Returns a random element from the provided list. If the list is empty
335     * then null is returned.
336     *
337     * @param <T>  the type of the returned object
338     * @param list the list to get an element from
339     * @return the randomly selected element
340     */
341    @Override
342    public <T> T getRandomElement(List<T> list) {
343        if (list.isEmpty()) {
344            return null;
345        }
346        return list.get(nextInt(list.size()));
347    }
348
349    /**
350     * Returns a random element from the provided ShortSet. If the set is empty
351     * then an exception is thrown.
352     * <p>
353     * <p>
354     * Requires iterating through a random amount of the elements in set, so performance depends on the size of set but
355     * is likely to be decent. This is mostly meant for internal use, the same as ShortSet.
356     * </p>
357     *
358     * @param set the ShortSet to get an element from
359     * @return the randomly selected element
360     */
361    public short getRandomElement(ShortSet set) {
362        if (set.size <= 0) {
363            throw new UnsupportedOperationException("ShortSet cannot be empty when getting a random element");
364        }
365        int n = nextInt(set.size);
366        short s = 0;
367        ShortSet.ShortSetIterator ssi = set.iterator();
368        while (n-- >= 0 && ssi.hasNext)
369            s = ssi.next();
370        ssi.reset();
371        return s;
372    }
373
374    /**
375     * Returns a random element from the provided Collection, which should have predictable iteration order if you want
376     * predictable behavior for identical RNG seeds, though it will get a random element just fine for any Collection
377     * (just not predictably in all cases). If you give this a Set, it should be a LinkedHashSet or some form of sorted
378     * Set like TreeSet if you want predictable results. Any List or Queue should be fine. Map does not implement
379     * Collection, thank you very much Java library designers, so you can't actually pass a Map to this, though you can
380     * pass the keys or values. If coll is empty, returns null.
381     * <p>
382     * <p>
383     * Requires iterating through a random amount of coll's elements, so performance depends on the size of coll but is
384     * likely to be decent, as long as iteration isn't unusually slow. This replaces {@code getRandomElement(Queue)},
385     * since Queue implements Collection and the older Queue-using implementation was probably less efficient.
386     * </p>
387     *
388     * @param <T>  the type of the returned object
389     * @param coll the Collection to get an element from; remember, Map does not implement Collection
390     * @return the randomly selected element
391     */
392    @Override
393    public <T> T getRandomElement(Collection<T> coll) {
394        int n;
395        if ((n = coll.size()) <= 0) {
396            return null;
397        }
398        n = nextInt(n);
399        T t = null;
400        Iterator<T> it = coll.iterator();
401        while (n-- >= 0 && it.hasNext())
402            t = it.next();
403        return t;
404    }
405
406        /*
407     * Returns a random elements from the provided queue. If the queue is empty
408         * then null is returned.
409         *
410         * <p>
411         * Requires iterating through a random amount of the elements in set, so
412         * performance depends on the size of set but is likely to be decent. This
413         * is mostly meant for internal use, the same as ShortSet.
414         * </p>
415         *
416         * @param <T> the type of the returned object
417         * @param list the list to get an element from
418         * @return the randomly selected element
419         */
420        /*
421        public <T> T getRandomElement(Queue<T> list) {
422                if (list.isEmpty()) {
423                        return null;
424                }
425                return new ArrayList<>(list).get(nextInt(list.size()));
426        }*/
427
428    /**
429     * Given a {@link List} l, this selects a random element of l to be the first value in the returned list l2. It
430     * retains the order of elements in l after that random element and makes them follow the first element in l2, and
431     * loops around to use elements from the start of l after it has placed the last element of l into l2.
432     * <br>
433     * Essentially, it does what it says on the tin. It randomly rotates the List l.
434     * <br>
435     * If you only need to iterate through a collection starting at a random point, the method getRandomStartIterable()
436     * should have better performance. This was GWT incompatible before GWT 2.8.0 became the version SquidLib uses; now
437     * this method works fine with GWT.
438     *
439     * @param l   A {@link List} that will not be modified by this method. All elements of this parameter will be
440     *            shared with the returned List.
441     * @param <T> No restrictions on type. Changes to elements of the returned List will be reflected in the parameter.
442     * @return A shallow copy of {@code l} that has been rotated so its first element has been randomly chosen
443     * from all possible elements but order is retained. Will "loop around" to contain element 0 of l after the last
444     * element of l, then element 1, etc.
445     */
446    public <T> List<T> randomRotation(final List<T> l) {
447        final int sz = l.size();
448        if (sz == 0)
449            return new ArrayList<>(0);
450
451                /*
452                 * Collections.rotate should prefer the best-performing way to rotate l,
453                 * which would be an in-place modification for ArrayLists and an append
454                 * to a sublist for Lists that don't support efficient random access.
455                 */
456        List<T> l2 = new ArrayList<>(l);
457        Collections.rotate(l2, nextInt(sz));
458        return l2;
459    }
460
461    /**
462     * Get an Iterable that starts at a random location in list and continues on through list in its current order.
463     * Loops around to the beginning after it gets to the end, stops when it returns to the starting location.
464     * <br>
465     * You should not modify {@code list} while you use the returned reference. And there'll be no
466     * ConcurrentModificationException to detect such erroneous uses.
467     *
468     * @param list A list <b>with a constant-time {@link List#get(int)} method</b> (otherwise performance degrades).
469     * @return An {@link Iterable} that iterates over {@code list} but start at
470     * a random index. If the chosen index is {@code i}, the iterator
471     * will return:
472     * {@code list[i]; list[i+1]; ...; list[list.length() - 1]; list[0]; list[i-1]}
473     */
474    public <T> Iterable<T> getRandomStartIterable(final List<T> list) {
475        final int sz = list.size();
476        if (sz == 0)
477            return new ArrayList<>(0);
478
479                /*
480                 * Here's a tricky bit: Defining 'start' here means that every Iterator
481                 * returned by the returned Iterable will have the same iteration order.
482                 * In other words, if you use more than once the returned Iterable,
483                 * you'll will see elements in the same order every time, which is
484                 * desirable.
485                 */
486        final int start = nextInt(sz);
487
488        return new Iterable<T>() {
489            @Override
490            public Iterator<T> iterator() {
491                return new Iterator<T>() {
492
493                    int next = -1;
494
495                    @Override
496                    public boolean hasNext() {
497                        return next != start;
498                    }
499
500                    @Override
501                    public T next() {
502                        if (next == start)
503                            throw new NoSuchElementException("Iteration terminated; check hasNext() before next()");
504                        if (next == -1)
505                                        /* First call */
506                            next = start;
507                        final T result = list.get(next);
508                        if (next == sz - 1)
509                                        /*
510                                         * Reached the list's end, let's continue from the list's
511                                         * left.
512                                         */
513                            next = 0;
514                        else
515                            next++;
516                        return result;
517                    }
518
519                    @Override
520                    public void remove() {
521                        throw new UnsupportedOperationException("Remove is not supported from a randomStartIterable");
522                    }
523
524                    @Override
525                    public String toString() {
526                        return "RandomStartIterator at index " + next;
527                    }
528                };
529            }
530        };
531    }
532
533
534    /**
535     * Mutates the array arr by switching the contents at pos1 and pos2.
536     * @param arr an array of T; must not be null
537     * @param pos1 an index into arr; must be at least 0 and no greater than arr.length
538     * @param pos2 an index into arr; must be at least 0 and no greater than arr.length
539     */
540    private static <T> void swap(T[] arr, int pos1, int pos2) {
541        final T tmp = arr[pos1];
542        arr[pos1] = arr[pos2];
543        arr[pos2] = tmp;
544    }
545
546    /**
547     * Shuffle an array using the Fisher-Yates algorithm and returns a shuffled copy.
548     * GWT-compatible since GWT 2.8.0, which is the default if you use libGDX 1.9.5 or higher.
549     * <br>
550     * <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%E2%80%93Yates_shuffle">Wikipedia has more on this algorithm</a>.
551     *
552     * @param elements an array of T; will not be modified
553     * @param <T>      can be any non-primitive type.
554     * @return a shuffled copy of elements
555     */
556    @Override
557    public <T> T[] shuffle(final T[] elements) {
558        final int size = elements.length;
559        final T[] array = Arrays.copyOf(elements, size);
560        for (int i = size; i > 1; i--) {
561            swap(array, i - 1, nextIntHasty(i));
562        }
563        return array;
564    }
565
566    /**
567     * Shuffles an array in-place using the Fisher-Yates algorithm.
568     * If you don't want the array modified, use {@link #shuffle(Object[], Object[])}.
569     * <br>
570     * <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%E2%80%93Yates_shuffle">Wikipedia has more on this algorithm</a>.
571     *
572     * @param elements an array of T; <b>will</b> be modified
573     * @param <T>      can be any non-primitive type.
574     * @return elements after shuffling it in-place
575     */
576    @Override
577    public <T> T[] shuffleInPlace(T[] elements) {
578        final int size = elements.length;
579        for (int i = size; i > 1; i--) {
580            swap(elements, i - 1, nextIntHasty(i));
581        }
582        return elements;
583    }
584
585    /**
586     * Shuffle an array using the Fisher-Yates algorithm. If possible, create a new array or reuse an existing array
587     * with the same length as elements and pass it in as dest; the dest array will contain the shuffled contents of
588     * elements and will also be returned as-is.
589     * <br>
590     * <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%E2%80%93Yates_shuffle">Wikipedia has more on this algorithm</a>.
591     *
592     * @param elements an array of T; will not be modified
593     * @param <T>      can be any non-primitive type.
594     * @param dest     Where to put the shuffle. If it does not have the same length as {@code elements}, this will use the
595     *                 randomPortion method of this class to fill the smaller dest.
596     * @return {@code dest} after modifications
597     */
598    @Override
599    public <T> T[] shuffle(T[] elements, T[] dest) {
600        if (dest.length != elements.length)
601            return randomPortion(elements, dest);
602        System.arraycopy(elements, 0, dest, 0, elements.length);
603        shuffleInPlace(dest);
604        return dest;
605    }
606
607    /**
608     * Shuffles a {@link Collection} of T using the Fisher-Yates algorithm and returns an ArrayList of T.
609     * <br>
610     * <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%E2%80%93Yates_shuffle">Wikipedia has more on this algorithm</a>.
611     * @param elements a Collection of T; will not be modified
612     * @param <T>      can be any non-primitive type.
613     * @return a shuffled ArrayList containing the whole of elements in pseudo-random order.
614     */
615    @Override
616    public <T> ArrayList<T> shuffle(Collection<T> elements) {
617        return shuffle(elements, null);
618    }
619
620    /**
621     * Shuffles a {@link Collection} of T using the Fisher-Yates algorithm. The result
622     * is allocated if {@code buf} is null or if {@code buf} isn't empty,
623     * otherwise {@code elements} is poured into {@code buf}.
624     * <br>
625     * <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%E2%80%93Yates_shuffle">Wikipedia has more on this algorithm</a>.
626     * @param elements a Collection of T; will not be modified
627     * @param <T>      can be any non-primitive type.
628     * @param buf a buffer as an ArrayList that will be filled with the shuffled contents of elements;
629     *            if null or non-empty, a new ArrayList will be allocated and returned
630     * @return a shuffled ArrayList containing the whole of elements in pseudo-random order.
631     */
632    @Override
633    public <T> ArrayList<T> shuffle(Collection<T> elements, /*@Nullable*/ ArrayList<T> buf) {
634        final ArrayList<T> al;
635        if (buf == null || !buf.isEmpty())
636            al = new ArrayList<>(elements);
637        else {
638            al = buf;
639            al.addAll(elements);
640        }
641        final int n = al.size();
642        for (int i = n; i > 1; i--) {
643            Collections.swap(al, nextInt(i), i - 1);
644        }
645        return al;
646    }
647    /**
648     * Shuffles a Collection of T items in-place using the Fisher-Yates algorithm.
649     * This only shuffles List data structures.
650     * If you don't want the array modified, use {@link #shuffle(Collection)}, which returns a List as well.
651     * <br>
652     * <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisher%E2%80%93Yates_shuffle">Wikipedia has more on this algorithm</a>.
653     *
654     * @param elements a Collection of T; <b>will</b> be modified
655     * @param <T>      can be any non-primitive type.
656     * @return elements after shuffling it in-place
657     */
658    @Override
659    public <T> List<T> shuffleInPlace(List<T> elements) {
660        final int n = elements.size();
661        for (int i = n; i > 1; i--) {
662            Collections.swap(elements, nextInt(i), i - 1);
663        }
664        return elements;
665    }
666
667
668    /**
669     * Generates a random permutation of the range from 0 (inclusive) to length (exclusive).
670     * Useful for passing to OrderedMap or OrderedSet's reorder() methods.
671     *
672     * @param length the size of the ordering to produce
673     * @return a random ordering containing all ints from 0 to length (exclusive)
674     */
675    @Override
676    public int[] randomOrdering(int length) {
677        if (length <= 0)
678            return new int[0];
679        return randomOrdering(length, new int[length]);
680    }
681
682    /**
683     * Generates a random permutation of the range from 0 (inclusive) to length (exclusive) and stores it in
684     * the dest parameter, avoiding allocations.
685     * Useful for passing to OrderedMap or OrderedSet's reorder() methods.
686     *
687     * @param length the size of the ordering to produce
688     * @param dest   the destination array; will be modified
689     * @return dest, filled with a random ordering containing all ints from 0 to length (exclusive)
690     */
691    @Override
692    public int[] randomOrdering(int length, int[] dest) {
693        if (dest == null) return null;
694
695        final int n = Math.min(length, dest.length);
696        for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
697            dest[i] = i;
698        }
699        for (int i = n - 1; i > 0; i--) {
700            final int r = nextIntHasty(i+1),
701                    t = dest[r];
702            dest[r] = dest[i];
703            dest[i] = t;
704        }
705        return dest;
706    }
707
708    /**
709     * Gets a random portion of a Collection and returns it as a new List. Will only use a given position in the given
710     * Collection at most once; does this by shuffling a copy of the Collection and getting a section of it.
711     *
712     * @param data  a Collection of T; will not be modified.
713     * @param count the non-negative number of elements to randomly take from data
714     * @param <T>   can be any non-primitive type
715     * @return a List of T that has length equal to the smaller of count or data.length
716     */
717    public <T> List<T> randomPortion(Collection<T> data, int count) {
718        return shuffle(data).subList(0, Math.min(count, data.size()));
719    }
720
721    /**
722     * Gets a random subrange of the non-negative ints from start (inclusive) to end (exclusive), using count elements.
723     * May return an empty array if the parameters are invalid (end is less than/equal to start, or start is negative).
724     *
725     * @param start the start of the range of numbers to potentially use (inclusive)
726     * @param end   the end of the range of numbers to potentially use (exclusive)
727     * @param count the total number of elements to use; will be less if the range is smaller than count
728     * @return an int array that contains at most one of each number in the range
729     */
730    public int[] randomRange(int start, int end, int count) {
731        if (end <= start || start < 0)
732            return new int[0];
733
734        int n = end - start;
735        final int[] data = new int[n];
736
737        for (int e = start, i = 0; e < end; e++) {
738            data[i++] = e;
739        }
740
741        for (int i = 0; i < n - 1; i++) {
742            final int r = i + nextInt(n - i), t = data[r];
743            data[r] = data[i];
744            data[i] = t;
745        }
746        final int[] array = new int[Math.min(count, n)];
747        System.arraycopy(data, 0, array, 0, Math.min(count, n));
748        return array;
749    }
750
751    /**
752     * Generates a random float with a curved distribution that centers on 0 (where it has a bias) and can (rarely)
753     * approach -1f and 1f, but not go beyond those bounds. This is similar to {@link Random#nextGaussian()} in that it
754     * uses a curved distribution, but it is not the same. The distribution for the values is similar to Irwin-Hall, and
755     * is frequently near 0 but not too-rarely near -1f or 1f. It cannot produce values greater than or equal to 1f, or
756     * less than -1f, but it can produce -1f.
757     * @return a deterministic float between -1f (inclusive) and 1f (exclusive), that is very likely to be close to 0f
758     */
759    public float nextCurvedFloat() {
760        final long start = random.nextLong();
761        return   (intBitsToFloat((int)start >>> 9 | 0x3F000000)
762                + intBitsToFloat((int) (start >>> 41) | 0x3F000000)
763                + intBitsToFloat(((int)(start ^ ~start >>> 20) & 0x007FFFFF) | 0x3F000000)
764                + intBitsToFloat(((int) (~start ^ start >>> 30) & 0x007FFFFF) | 0x3F000000)
765                - 3f);
766    }
767
768
769    /**
770     * Gets a random double between 0.0 inclusive and 1.0 exclusive.
771     * This returns a maximum of 0.9999999999999999 because that is the largest double value that is less than 1.0 .
772     *
773     * @return a double between 0.0 (inclusive) and 0.9999999999999999 (inclusive)
774     */
775    @Override
776    public double nextDouble() {
777        return (random.nextLong() & 0x1fffffffffffffL) * 0x1p-53;
778        //this is here for a record of another possibility; it can't generate quite a lot of possible values though
779        //return Double.longBitsToDouble(0x3FF0000000000000L | random.nextLong() >>> 12) - 1.0;
780    }
781
782    /**
783     * This returns a random double between 0.0 (inclusive) and outer (exclusive). The value for outer can be positive
784     * or negative. Because of how math on doubles works, there are at most 2 to the 53 values this can return for any
785     * given outer bound, and very large values for outer will not necessarily produce all numbers you might expect.
786     *
787     * @param outer the outer exclusive bound as a double; can be negative or positive
788     * @return a double between 0.0 (inclusive) and outer (exclusive)
789     */
790    @Override
791    public double nextDouble(final double outer) {
792        return (random.nextLong() & 0x1fffffffffffffL) * 0x1p-53 * outer;
793    }
794
795    /**
796     * Gets a random float between 0.0f inclusive and 1.0f exclusive.
797     * This returns a maximum of 0.99999994 because that is the largest float value that is less than 1.0f .
798     *
799     * @return a float between 0f (inclusive) and 0.99999994f (inclusive)
800     */
801    @Override
802    public float nextFloat() {
803        return random.next(24) * 0x1p-24f;
804    }
805    /**
806     * This returns a random float between 0.0f (inclusive) and outer (exclusive). The value for outer can be positive
807     * or negative. Because of how math on floats works, there are at most 2 to the 24 values this can return for any
808     * given outer bound, and very large values for outer will not necessarily produce all numbers you might expect.
809     *
810     * @param outer the outer exclusive bound as a float; can be negative or positive
811     * @return a float between 0f (inclusive) and outer (exclusive)
812     */
813    @Override
814    public float nextFloat(final float outer) {
815        return random.next(24) * 0x1p-24f * outer;
816    }
817
818    /**
819     * Get a random bit of state, interpreted as true or false with approximately equal likelihood.
820     * This may have better behavior than {@code rng.next(1)}, depending on the RandomnessSource implementation; the
821     * default DiverRNG will behave fine, as will LightRNG and ThrustAltRNG (these all use similar algorithms), but
822     * the  normally-high-quality XoRoRNG will produce very predictable output with {@code rng.next(1)} and very good
823     * output with {@code rng.nextBoolean()}. This is a known and considered flaw of Xoroshiro128+, the algorithm used
824     * by XoRoRNG, and a large number of generators have lower quality on the least-significant bit than the most-
825     * significant bit, where this method only checks the most-significant bit.
826     * @return a random boolean.
827     */
828    @Override
829    public boolean nextBoolean() {
830        return nextLong() < 0L;
831    }
832
833    /**
834     * Get a random long between Long.MIN_VALUE to Long.MAX_VALUE (both inclusive).
835     *
836     * @return a 64-bit random long.
837     */
838    @Override
839    public long nextLong() {
840        return random.nextLong();
841    }
842
843    /**
844     * Gets a pseudo-random long between 0 and bound. 
845     * Exclusive on bound (which must be positive), with an inner bound of 0 If bound is negative or 0, this always
846     * returns 0. You can use {@link #nextSignedLong(long)} to use a negative bound. The technique that 
847     * <br>
848     * Credit for this method goes to <a href="https://oroboro.com/large-random-in-range/">Rafael Baptista's blog</a>
849     * for the original idea, and the JDK10 Math class' usage of Karatsuba multiplication for the current algorithm. 
850     * This method is drastically faster than the previous implementation when the bound varies often (roughly 4x
851     * faster, possibly more). It also always gets exactly one random long, so by default it advances the state as much
852     * as {@link #nextLong()}.
853     * 
854     * @param bound the outer exclusive bound; should be positive, otherwise this always returns 0L
855     * @return a random long between 0 (inclusive) and bound (exclusive)
856     */
857    public long nextLong(long bound) {
858        long rand = random.nextLong();
859        if (bound <= 0) return 0;
860        final long randLow = rand & 0xFFFFFFFFL;
861        final long boundLow = bound & 0xFFFFFFFFL;
862        rand >>>= 32;
863        bound >>>= 32;
864        final long a = rand * bound;
865        final long b = randLow * boundLow;
866        return (((b >>> 32) + (rand + randLow) * (bound + boundLow) - a - b) >>> 32) + a;
867    }
868    /**
869     * Exclusive on bound (which may be positive or negative), with an inner bound of 0.
870     * If bound is negative this returns a negative long; if bound is positive this returns a positive long. The bound
871     * can even be 0, which will cause this to return 0L every time. This uses a biased technique to get numbers from
872     * large ranges, but the amount of bias is incredibly small (expected to be under 1/1000 if enough random ranged
873     * numbers are requested, which is about the same as an unbiased method that was also considered).It may have
874     * noticeable bias if the generator's period is exhausted by only calls to this method. Unlike all unbiased methods,
875     * this advances the state by an equivalent to exactly one call to {@link #nextLong()}, where rejection sampling
876     * would sometimes advance by one call, but other times by arbitrarily many more.
877     * <br>
878     * Credit for this method goes to <a href="https://oroboro.com/large-random-in-range/">Rafael Baptista's blog</a>
879     * for the original idea, and the JDK10 Math class' usage of Hacker's Delight code for the current algorithm. 
880     * This method is drastically faster than the previous implementation when the bound varies often (roughly 4x
881     * faster, possibly more). It also always gets exactly one random long, so by default it advances the state as much
882     * as {@link #nextLong()}.
883     *
884     * @param bound the outer exclusive bound; can be positive or negative
885     * @return a random long between 0 (inclusive) and bound (exclusive)
886     */
887    public long nextSignedLong(long bound) {
888        long rand = random.nextLong();
889        final long randLow = rand & 0xFFFFFFFFL;
890        final long boundLow = bound & 0xFFFFFFFFL;
891        rand >>>= 32;
892        bound >>= 32;
893        final long t = rand * boundLow + (randLow * boundLow >>> 32);
894        return rand * bound + (t >> 32) + (randLow * bound + (t & 0xFFFFFFFFL) >> 32);
895    }
896
897    /**
898     * Returns a random non-negative integer between 0 (inclusive) and the given bound (exclusive),
899     * or 0 if the bound is 0. The bound can be negative, which will produce 0 or a negative result.
900     * This is almost identical to the earlier {@link #nextIntHasty(int)} except that it will perform better when the
901     * RandomnessSource this uses natively produces 32-bit output. It was added to the existing nextIntHasty() so
902     * existing code using nextIntHasty would produce the same results, but new code matches the API with
903     * {@link #nextSignedLong(long)}. This is implemented slightly differently in {@link AbstractRNG}, and different
904     * results should be expected when using code based on that abstract class.
905     * <br>
906     * Credit goes to Daniel Lemire, http://lemire.me/blog/2016/06/27/a-fast-alternative-to-the-modulo-reduction/
907     *
908     * @param bound the outer bound (exclusive), can be negative or positive
909     * @return the found number
910     */
911    public int nextSignedInt(final int bound) {
912        return (int) ((bound * (long)random.next(31)) >> 31);
913    }
914
915    /**
916     * Returns a random non-negative integer below the given bound, or 0 if the bound is 0 or
917     * negative. Always makes one call to the {@link RandomnessSource#next(int)} method of the RandomnessSource that
918     * would be returned by {@link #getRandomness()}, even if bound is 0 or negative, to avoid branching and also to
919     * ensure consistent advancement rates for the RandomnessSource (this can be important if you use a
920     * {@link SkippingRandomness} and want to go back before a result was produced).
921     * <br>
922     * This method changed a fair amount on April 5, 2018 to better support RandomnessSource implementations with a
923     * slower nextLong() method, such as {@link Lathe32RNG}, and to avoid branching/irregular state advancement/modulus
924     * operations. It is now almost identical to {@link #nextIntHasty(int)}, but won't return negative results if bound
925     * is negative (matching its previous behavior). This may have statistical issues (small ones) if bound is very
926     * large (the estimate is still at least a bound of a billion or more before issues are observable). Consider
927     * {@link #nextSignedInt(int)} if the bound should be allowed to be negative; {@link #nextIntHasty(int)} is here for
928     * compatibility with earlier versions, but the two methods are very similar.
929     * <br>
930     * Credit goes to Daniel Lemire, http://lemire.me/blog/2016/06/27/a-fast-alternative-to-the-modulo-reduction/
931     *
932     * @param bound the upper bound (exclusive)
933     * @return the found number
934     */
935    @Override
936    public int nextInt(final int bound) {
937        return (int) ((bound * ((long)random.next(31))) >>> 31) & ~(bound >> 31);
938//        int threshold = (0x7fffffff - bound + 1) % bound;
939//        for (; ; ) {
940//            int bits = random.next(31);
941//            if (bits >= threshold)
942//                return bits % bound;
943//        }
944    }
945
946    /**
947     * Returns a random non-negative integer between 0 (inclusive) and the given bound (exclusive),
948     * or 0 if the bound is 0. The bound can be negative, which will produce 0 or a negative result.
949     * Uses an aggressively optimized technique that has some bias, but mostly for values of
950     * bound over 1 billion. This method is no more "hasty" than {@link #nextInt(int)}, but it is a little
951     * faster than that method because this avoids special behavior for when bound is negative.
952     * <br>
953     * Credit goes to Daniel Lemire, http://lemire.me/blog/2016/06/27/a-fast-alternative-to-the-modulo-reduction/
954     *
955     * @param bound the outer bound (exclusive), can be negative or positive
956     * @return the found number
957     */
958    public int nextIntHasty(final int bound) {
959        return (int) ((bound * (random.nextLong() & 0x7FFFFFFFL)) >> 31);
960    }
961
962    /**
963     * Generates random bytes and places them into the given byte array, modifying it in-place.
964     * The number of random bytes produced is equal to the length of the byte array. Unlike the
965     * method in java.util.Random, this generates 8 bytes at a time, which can be more efficient
966     * with many RandomnessSource types than the JDK's method that generates 4 bytes at a time.
967     * <br>
968     * Adapted from code in the JavaDocs of {@link Random#nextBytes(byte[])}.
969     * <br>
970     * @param  bytes the byte array to fill with random bytes; cannot be null, will be modified
971     * @throws NullPointerException if the byte array is null
972     */
973    public void nextBytes(final byte[] bytes) {
974        for (int i = 0; i < bytes.length; )
975            for (long r = random.nextLong(), n = Math.min(bytes.length - i, 8); n-- > 0; r >>>= 8)
976                bytes[i++] = (byte) r;
977    }
978
979    /**
980     * Get a random integer between Integer.MIN_VALUE to Integer.MAX_VALUE (both inclusive).
981     *
982     * @return a 32-bit random int.
983     */
984    @Override
985    public int nextInt() {
986        return random.next(32);
987    }

989    /**
990     * Get up to 32 bits (inclusive) of random output; the int this produces
991     * will not require more than {@code bits} bits to represent.
992     *
993     * @param bits an int between 1 and 32, both inclusive
994     * @return a random number that fits in the specified number of bits
995     */
996    @Override
997    public int next(int bits) {
998        return random.next(bits);
999    }
1000
1001    public RandomnessSource getRandomness() {
1002        return random;
1003    }
1004
1005    public void setRandomness(RandomnessSource random) {
1006        this.random = random;
1007    }

1009    /**
1010     * Creates a copy of this RNG; it will generate the same random numbers, given the same calls in order, as this RNG
1011     * at the point copy() is called. The copy will not share references with this RNG.
1012     *
1013     * @return a copy of this RNG
1014     */
1015    @Override
1016    public RNG copy() {
1017        return new RNG(random.copy());
1018    }
1019
1020    /**
1021     * Generates a random 64-bit long with a number of '1' bits (Hamming weight) equal on average to bitCount.
1022     * For example, calling this with a parameter of 32 will be equivalent to calling nextLong() on this object's
1023     * RandomnessSource (it doesn't consider overridden nextLong() methods, where present, on subclasses of RNG).
1024     * Calling this with a parameter of 16 will have on average 16 of the 64 bits in the returned long set to '1',
1025     * distributed pseudo-randomly, while a parameter of 47 will have on average 47 bits set. This can be useful for
1026     * certain code that uses bits to represent data but needs a different ratio of set bits to unset bits than 1:1.
1027     * <br>
1028     * This method is deprecated because it really only finds usage in GreasedRegion, so it has been moved there and
1029     * made so it can take any RandomnessSource as a parameter, including any IRNG or RNG.
1030     *
1031     * @param bitCount an int, only considered if between 0 and 64, that is the average number of bits to set
1032     * @return a 64-bit long that, on average, should have bitCount bits set to 1, potentially anywhere in the long
1033     * @deprecated see the version in GreasedRegion, {@link GreasedRegion#approximateBits(RandomnessSource, int)}
1034     */
1035    @Deprecated
1036    public long approximateBits(int bitCount) {
1037        if (bitCount <= 0)
1038            return 0L;
1039        if (bitCount >= 64)
1040            return -1L;
1041        if (bitCount == 32)
1042            return random.nextLong();
1043        boolean high = bitCount > 32;
1044        int altered = (high ? 64 - bitCount : bitCount), lsb = NumberTools.lowestOneBit(altered);
1045        long data = random.nextLong();
1046        for (int i = lsb << 1; i <= 16; i <<= 1) {
1047            if ((altered & i) == 0)
1048                data &= random.nextLong();
1049            else
1050                data |= random.nextLong();
1051        }
1052        return high ? ~(random.nextLong() & data) : (random.nextLong() & data);
1053    }
1054
1055    /**
1056     * Gets a somewhat-random long with exactly 32 bits set; in each pair of bits starting at bit 0 and bit 1, then bit
1057     * 2 and bit 3, up to bit 62 and bit 3, one bit will be 1 and one bit will be 0 in each pair.
1058     * <br>
1059     * Not exactly general-use; meant for generating data for GreasedRegion. This is deprecated in favor of the version
1060     * in GreasedRegion.
1061     * @return a random long with 32 "1" bits, distributed so exactly one bit is "1" for each pair of bits
1062     * @deprecated See {@link GreasedRegion#randomInterleave(RandomnessSource)} for where this will be moved
1063     */
1064    @Deprecated
1065    public long randomInterleave() {
1066        long bits = nextLong() & 0xFFFFFFFFL, ib = ~bits & 0xFFFFFFFFL;
1067        bits |= (bits << 16);
1068        ib |= (ib << 16);
1069        bits &= 0x0000FFFF0000FFFFL;
1070        ib &= 0x0000FFFF0000FFFFL;
1071        bits |= (bits << 8);
1072        ib |= (ib << 8);
1073        bits &= 0x00FF00FF00FF00FFL;
1074        ib &= 0x00FF00FF00FF00FFL;
1075        bits |= (bits << 4);
1076        ib |= (ib << 4);
1077        bits &= 0x0F0F0F0F0F0F0F0FL;
1078        ib &= 0x0F0F0F0F0F0F0F0FL;
1079        bits |= (bits << 2);
1080        ib |= (ib << 2);
1081        bits &= 0x3333333333333333L;
1082        ib &= 0x3333333333333333L;
1083        bits |= (bits << 1);
1084        ib |= (ib << 1);
1085        bits &= 0x5555555555555555L;
1086        ib &= 0x5555555555555555L;
1087        return (bits | (ib << 1));
1088    }
1089
1090    /**
1091     * Gets the minimum random long between 0 and {@code bound} generated out of {@code trials} generated numbers.
1092     * Useful for when numbers should have a strong bias toward zero, but all possible values are between 0, inclusive,
1093     * and bound, exclusive.
1094     * @param bound the outer exclusive bound; may be negative or positive
1095     * @param trials how many numbers to generate and get the minimum of
1096     * @return the minimum generated long between 0 and bound out of the specified amount of trials
1097     */
1098    public long minLongOf(final long bound, final int trials)
1099    {
1100        long value = nextSignedLong(bound);
1101        for (int i = 1; i < trials; i++) {
1102            value = Math.min(value, nextSignedLong(bound));
1103        }
1104        return value;
1105    }
1106    /**
1107     * Gets the maximum random long between 0 and {@code bound} generated out of {@code trials} generated numbers.
1108     * Useful for when numbers should have a strong bias away from zero, but all possible values are between 0,
1109     * inclusive, and bound, exclusive.
1110     * @param bound the outer exclusive bound; may be negative or positive
1111     * @param trials how many numbers to generate and get the maximum of
1112     * @return the maximum generated long between 0 and bound out of the specified amount of trials
1113     */
1114    public long maxLongOf(final long bound, final int trials)
1115    {
1116        long value = nextSignedLong(bound);
1117        for (int i = 1; i < trials; i++) {
1118            value = Math.max(value, nextSignedLong(bound));
1119        }
1120        return value;
1121    }
1122
1123    /**
1124     * Gets the minimum random int between 0 and {@code bound} generated out of {@code trials} generated numbers.
1125     * Useful for when numbers should have a strong bias toward zero, but all possible values are between 0, inclusive,
1126     * and bound, exclusive.
1127     * @param bound the outer exclusive bound; may be negative or positive
1128     * @param trials how many numbers to generate and get the minimum of
1129     * @return the minimum generated int between 0 and bound out of the specified amount of trials
1130     */
1131    public int minIntOf(final int bound, final int trials)
1132    {
1133        int value = nextSignedInt(bound);
1134        for (int i = 1; i < trials; i++) {
1135            value = Math.min(value, nextSignedInt(bound));
1136        }
1137        return value;
1138    }

1224    @Override
1225    public String toString() {
1226        return "RNG with Randomness Source " + random;
1227    }
1228
1229    @Override
1230    public boolean equals(Object o) {
1231        if (this == o) return true;
1232        if (!(o instanceof RNG)) return false;
1233
1234        RNG rng = (RNG) o;
1235
1236        return random.equals(rng.random);
1237    }
1238
1239    @Override
1240    public int hashCode() {
1241        return 31 * random.hashCode();
1242    }
1243
1244    /**
1245     * Gets a random portion of data (an array), assigns that portion to output (an array) so that it fills as much as
1246     * it can, and then returns output. Will only use a given position in the given data at most once; uses a Feistel
1247     * Network to accomplish this without allocations. Internally, makes 2 calls to {@link #nextInt()}, regardless of
1248     * the data being randomized.
1249     * <br>
1250     * Uses approximately the same code as {@link LowStorageShuffler}, but without any object or array allocations.
1251     *
1252     * @param data   an array of T; will not be modified.
1253     * @param output an array of T that will be overwritten; should always be instantiated with the portion length
1254     * @param <T>    can be any non-primitive type.
1255     * @return output, after {@code Math.min(output.length, data.length)} unique items have been put into it from data
1256     */
1257    @Override
1258    public <T> T[] randomPortion(T[] data, T[] output) {
1259        final int length = data.length, n = Math.min(length, output.length);
1260        // calculate next power of 4.  Needed since the balanced Feistel network needs
1261        // an even number of bits to work with
1262        int pow4 = HashCommon.nextPowerOfTwo(length);
1263        if((pow4 & 0x55555554) == 0)
1264            pow4 = HashCommon.nextPowerOfTwo(pow4);
1265        pow4--;
1266        // calculate our left and right masks to split our indices for the Feistel network
1267        final int halfBits = Integer.bitCount(pow4) >>> 1;
1268        final int rightMask = pow4 >>> halfBits;
1269        final int leftMask = pow4 ^ rightMask;
1270        final int key0 = nextInt(), key1 = nextInt();
1271        int index = 0;
1272        for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
1273            int shuffleIndex;
1274            // index is the index to start searching for the next number at
1275            while (index <= pow4)
1276            {
1277                // break our index into the left and right half
1278                int left = (index & leftMask) >>> halfBits;
1279                int right = (index & rightMask);
1280                // do 2 Feistel rounds
1281                int newRight = left ^ (LowStorageShuffler.round(right, key0) & rightMask);
1282                left = right;
1283                right = newRight;
1284                newRight = left ^ (LowStorageShuffler.round(right, key1) & rightMask);
1285                shuffleIndex = right << halfBits | newRight;
1286                index++;
1287
1288                // if we found a valid index, return it!
1289                if (shuffleIndex < length) {
1290                    output[i] = data[shuffleIndex];
1291                    break;
1292                }
1293            }
1294        }
1295        return output;
1296    }
1297
1298
1299    /**
1300     * Gets a random double between 0.0 inclusive and 1.0 inclusive.
1301     *
1302     * @return a double between 0.0 (inclusive) and 1.0 (inclusive)
1303     */
1304    public double nextDoubleInclusive()
1305    {
1306        return (random.nextLong() & 0x1fffffffffffffL) * 0x1.0000000000001p-53;
1307    }
1308
1309    /**
1310     * This returns a random double between 0.0 (inclusive) and outer (inclusive). The value for outer can be positive
1311     * or negative. Because of how math on doubles works, there are at most 2 to the 53 values this can return for any
1312     * given outer bound, and very large values for outer will not necessarily produce all numbers you might expect.
1313     *
1314     * @param outer the outer inclusive bound as a double; can be negative or positive
1315     * @return a double between 0.0 (inclusive) and outer (inclusive)
1316     */
1317    public double nextDoubleInclusive(final double outer) {
1318        return (random.nextLong() & 0x1fffffffffffffL) * 0x1.0000000000001p-53 * outer;
1319    }
1320
1321    /**
1322     * Gets a random float between 0.0f inclusive and 1.0f inclusive.
1323     *
1324     * @return a float between 0f (inclusive) and 1f (inclusive)
1325     */
1326    public float nextFloatInclusive() {
1327        return random.next(24) * 0x1.000002p-24f;
1328    }
1329
1330    /**
1331     * This returns a random float between 0.0f (inclusive) and outer (inclusive). The value for outer can be positive
1332     * or negative. Because of how math on floats works, there are at most 2 to the 24 values this can return for any
1333     * given outer bound, and very large values for outer will not necessarily produce all numbers you might expect.
1334     *
1335     * @param outer the outer inclusive bound as a float; can be negative or positive
1336     * @return a float between 0f (inclusive) and outer (inclusive)
1337     */
1338    public float nextFloatInclusive(final float outer) {
1339        return random.next(24) * 0x1.000002p-24f * outer;
1340    }
1341
1342
1343
1344
1345
1346    /**
1347     * Gets a random Coord that has x between 0 (inclusive) and width (exclusive) and y between 0 (inclusive)
1348     * and height (exclusive). This makes one call to randomLong to generate (more than) 31 random bits for
1349     * each axis, and should be very fast. Remember that Coord values are cached in a pool that starts able to
1350     * hold up to 255 x and 255 y for positive values, and the pool should be grown with the static method
1351     * Coord.expandPool() in order to efficiently use larger Coord values. If width and height are very large,
1352     * greater than 100,000 for either, this particular method may show bias toward certain positions due to
1353     * the "hasty" technique used to reduce the random numbers to the given size, but because most maps in
1354     * tile-based games are relatively small, this technique should be fine.
1355     * <br>
1356     * Credit goes to Daniel Lemire, http://lemire.me/blog/2016/06/27/a-fast-alternative-to-the-modulo-reduction/
1357     *
1358     * @param width  the upper bound (exclusive) for x coordinates
1359     * @param height the upper bound (exclusive) for y coordinates
1360     * @return a random Coord between (0,0) inclusive and (width,height) exclusive
1361     */
1362    public Coord nextCoord(int width, int height) {
1363        final long n = random.nextLong();
1364        return Coord.get((int) ((width * (n >>> 33)) >> 31), (int) ((height * (n & 0x7FFFFFFFL)) >> 31));
1365    }
1366
1367    /**
1368     * Use that to get random cells in a rectangular map.
1369     *
1370     * @param width  The map's width (bounds the x-coordinate in returned coords).
1371     * @param height The map's height (bounds the y-coordinate in returned coords).
1372     * @param size   The number of elements in the returned iterable or anything
1373     *               negative for no bound (in which case the iterator is infinite, it's
1374     *               up to you to bound your iteration).
1375     * @return An iterable that returns random cells in the rectangle (0,0)
1376     * (inclusive) .. (width, height) (exclusive).
1377     */
1378    public Iterable<Coord> getRandomCellsIterable(final int width, final int height, final int size) {
1379        return new Iterable<Coord>() {
1380            @Override
1381            public Iterator<Coord> iterator() {
1382                return new Iterator<Coord>() {
1383
1384                    /**
1385                     * The number of elements returned so far
1386                     */
1387                    int returned = 0;
1388
1389                    @Override
1390                    public boolean hasNext() {
1391                        return size < 0 || returned < size;
1392                    }
1393
1394                    @Override
1395                    public Coord next() {
1396                        if (!hasNext())
1397                            throw new NoSuchElementException();
1398                        returned++;
1399                        return nextCoord(width, height);
1400                    }
1401
1402                    @Override
1403                    public void remove() {
1404                        throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
1405                    }
1406                };
1407            }
1408        };
1409    }
1410
1411    /**
1412     * Gets an array of unique Coords, from (startX,startY) inclusive to (startX+width,startY+height) exclusive, in a
1413     * random order, with the array containing {@code width * height} items.
1414     *
1415     * @param startX the inclusive starting x position
1416     * @param startY the inclusive starting y position
1417     * @param width  the width of the space to place Coords in, extending from startX
1418     * @param height the height of the space to place Coords in, extending from startY
1419     * @return an array containing {@code width * height} Coord items in random order, inside the given bounds
1420     */
1421    public Coord[] getRandomUniqueCells(final int startX, final int startY, final int width, final int height) {
1422        if (width <= 0 || height <= 0)
1423            return new Coord[0];
1424        return getRandomUniqueCells(startX, startY, width, height, new Coord[width * height]);
1425    }
1426
1427    /**
1428     * Gets an array of unique Coords, from (startX,startY) inclusive to (startX+width,startY+height) exclusive, in a
1429     * random order, with the array containing {@code Math.min(width * height, size)} items. If size is less than width
1430     * times height, then not all Coords in the space will be used.
1431     *
1432     * @param startX the inclusive starting x position
1433     * @param startY the inclusive starting y position
1434     * @param width  the width of the space to place Coords in, extending from startX
1435     * @param height the height of the space to place Coords in, extending from startY
1436     * @param size   the size of the array to return; only matters if it is smaller than {@code width * height}
1437     * @return an array containing {@code Math.min(width * height, size)} Coord items in random order, inside the given bounds
1438     */
1439    public Coord[] getRandomUniqueCells(final int startX, final int startY, final int width, final int height,
1440                                        final int size) {
1441        if (width <= 0 || height <= 0 || size <= 0)
1442            return new Coord[0];
1443        return getRandomUniqueCells(startX, startY, width, height, new Coord[Math.min(width * height, size)]);
1444    }
1445
1446    /**
1447     * Assigns to dest an array of unique Coords, from (startX,startY) inclusive to (startX+width,startY+height)
1448     * exclusive, in a random order, with dest after this is called containing the lesser of {@code width * height} or
1449     * {@code dest.length} items. This will not allocate a new array for dest, but will create a temporary int array for
1450     * handling the shuffle.
1451     *
1452     * @param startX the inclusive starting x position
1453     * @param startY the inclusive starting y position
1454     * @param width  the width of the space to place Coords in, extending from startX
1455     * @param height the height of the space to place Coords in, extending from startY
1456     * @param dest   a Coord array that will be modified to contain randomly-ordered Coords, but will not be resized
1457     * @return dest, now with up to its first {@code width * height} items assigned to random Coords inside the given bounds
1458     */
1459    public Coord[] getRandomUniqueCells(final int startX, final int startY, final int width, final int height,
1460                                        final Coord[] dest) {
1461        if (width <= 0 || height <= 0 || dest == null || dest.length <= 0)
1462            return dest;
1463        int[] o = randomOrdering(width * height);
1464        for (int i = 0; i < o.length && i < dest.length; i++) {
1465            dest[i] = Coord.get(startX + o[i] % width, startY + o[i] / width);
1466        }
1467        return dest;
1468    }
1469
1470    /**
1471     * Returns this RNG in a way that can be deserialized even if only {@link IRNG}'s methods can be called.
1472     * @return a {@link Serializable} view of this RNG; always {@code this}
1473     */
1474    @Override
1475    public Serializable toSerializable() {
1476        return this;
1477    }
1478}
